texts.shortText:
Delicate bright pink to red species emerging from a rhizome-like holdfast and forming small clumps. Each frond arranged in a single plane and with prolific branching. Branches may be simple, elongate and curved, tapering to a sharp tip (awl-shaped), or be shorter and strongly bent, bearing 2-3 curved laterals along their concave margin (these in turn may also bear smaller teeth).

Appears to be more common and grow much larger and more sparely-branched along the east and south coast, suggesting that the smaller, more compact Western Cape form may be a different species?
On south coast reported to be up to about 150 mm tall, but specimens from False Bay much smaller at 20-30 mm. Branches less than 1 mm in diameter.

Global: South Africa and Angola.

Local/Regional: False Bay to KwaZulu-Natal.
Very attractive and distinctively coloured species found from low intertidal to shallow sublittoral.

Other species of Plocamium known to have a complex life cycle consisting of three phases. The diploid sporophyte produces haploid spores which develop onto separate male and female gametophytes. These look similar to the sporophyte, except for details of the small fertile branches in the axils of the fronds. The female gametophyte retains her eggs while they are fertilised by the male gametes and develop into wart-like discs, and these are finally releases as asexual carpospores that develop back into the sporophyte generation!

There are several other regional species of Plocamium, all with curved branches. This species can be identified by its small size and delicate structure, flat branching pattern and bright pink colour.
